utterances: Toni's right.
I mean, there is good stuff happening.
It's that in-between part where Toni and I just gotta find something.
Right.
We can keep going until maybe we can take advantage of those things when those projects are running(ph).
Unemployment benefits run out at 100 weeks, don't they?
Ninety-nine, sir.
You worried about health care?
In that regard, no. As retired military, I am set as far as the medical side.
That takes a big chunk of worry out of it.
Toni, what are what are your concerns now?
The same concerns I had in 2010.
I don't have any benefits.
I don't have any health care.

I'm actually living on my student loans - I hate to admit it - and actually those came due and I had to call them up and - you know, it's funny because I'm writing my own blog post, 2010: A Year in Review.
And I basically wrote that what I've learned from this unemployment - on a positive note, I don't need much to survive.
I don't need, you know, material things.
I remember my father, God rest his soul, I remember him saying, you know, if you have your health you have everything.
And I am very grateful really for the small things that I think a lot of people take for granted.
Randall Jameson, Toni Chinakas, thanks so much.
Thank you, Scott.
Always a pleasure.
Thank you.
Take care.
Talk to you later.
Bye.
Thanks.
OK, bye.
Nearly a third of transgender Americans lack regular access to health care.
That finding comes in a new poll by NPR, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the Harvard T.H.
Chan School of Public Health.
NPR's Neda Ulaby has more.
There's a homeless shelter in Washington, D.C., for LGBT youth like this young woman standing outside.
I'm Ruby Barbie Doll.
Ruby Barbie Doll was kicked out of her home for being transgender.
She does not have regular access to health care.
Many of the clients here are among that 31 percent, says the transgender woman who founded Casa Ruby.
Thirty-one percent - it's a lot.
Ruby Corado cues in on one crucial word - regular access to health care.
And what does regular health means (ph) - preventable.
Preventable problems including HIV and cancer.
In an NPR poll, 22 percent of transgender people said they've avoided doctors or health care for fear they'd be discriminated against.
Medical professionals have asked Corado insensitive questions like...
What are you?
Your trans status is on parade for people to make fun of you.
Right now it's very hard for a lot of people even to find a primary care provider who is willing to work with them.
Kellan Baker is an academic at Johns Hopkins University.
He studies how health policies affect gay, lesbian, queer and transgender Americans.
He says a number of insurance companies will not cover care related to gender transition such as hormones or surgery.
You're not able to get health insurance coverage.
You can't get health care that you need to make sure that how you look aligns with who you are.
Transition can take many forms, Baker says.
Surgery on reproductive organs is expensive, so many people leave them alone.
Imagine getting an annual physical as a trans man with a uterus or a trans woman with a prostate and being told...
What do you mean you need a cervical pap test for a man or a prostate exam for a woman?
How do we compute that?
You shouldn't have that part, so we don't know what to do with you.
Baker says trans people have died because they've slipped through those cracks, their bodies treated like they don't make any sense.
But there is someplace you can go if you're a transgender person looking for high-quality, low-cost health care.
We're in Richmond, Va., the Virginia League for Planned Parenthood.
Planned Parenthood trains its staff nationwide to be sensitive to transgender people.
Its doctors can give trans women prostate exams, trans men pap smears.
This Planned Parenthood in Richmond provides hundreds of patients with hormone therapy.
Afton Bradley works on ensuring trans patients are treated well from the minute they walk in the clinic's door.
Does our front desk know how to be affirming?
Is our electronic health record affirming?
Does it ask about pronouns and gender identity?

Bradley says this Planned Parenthood can handle trans-specific problems like what happens when a transwoman injects herself with building-grade silicone to get feminine curves or a trans man buys black market testosterone or injures himself by binding his chest with duct tape.
Ryan Brazell is a trans man who gets his care at Planned Parenthood.
He remembers his first visit here.
I went out to my car and was like - I felt really weird, and it took me a couple of days to figure out why.
And it was because it was the first time that I had a health care experience that I was happy with it.
I - and I didn't really know what that felt like until I had had that experience at Planned Parenthood.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Corado points to the dozens of trans people violently killed just this year across the country.
Another public health issue - almost 20 percent of black transgender women are HIV positive.
Compare that, says Corado, to the general population, which is only 3 percent.

It is very likely, particularly if you are a transgender woman of color, that you will die from HIV, that you will die from AIDS, that you will die stabbed or killed, that you will die from some kind of cancer or suicide.
All potentially preventable.
A recent survey of trans people says 40 percent have attempted suicide in their lifetimes, says Afton Bradley at the Richmond, Va., Planned Parenthood.
What we see is this dramatic reduction in those attempts when people have access to affirmative care.
Affirmative care meaning treating trans people like people.
Bradley says it's not that hard.
Neda Ulaby, NPR News.
You're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
Time now for your letters.
And we received a few about the interview last week with Kenneth Briggs, author of Double Crossed: Uncovering the Catholic Church's Betrayal of American Nuns.
Joy Mullett(ph) of Houston, Texas wrote, You know that wavy mouth that Peanuts characters wear when they're in a situation that is as much bitter as it is sweet?
Although it was over 50 years ago, I clearly remember that mouth on my first grade nun as she said that little boys were closer to Jesus than girls because they could become priests.
Of course, nuns went too far in the eyes of the male hierarchy.
Any action at all would be too far.
David McFadden(ph) of New Orleans had a different view.
The book deals in a confused way with the following set of circumstances.
Orders of nuns abrogated their traditions and as a result suffered the inevitable consequence of a collapse of interest in those orders.
As vocations plummeted, clergy in Rome and elsewhere tried to contain the damage, but the collapse could not be undone.
And whom does Mr. Briggs blame for the collapse?
He blames the clergy, of course.
Leveling yet another inane conspiracy theory against the Catholic church.
John Hamilton's piece on autism and language and the work of Dr. Temple Grandin also drew a number of letters.
Rita Winston(ph) wrote, I have never understood why Dr. Grandin is used as an example of autistic people lacking empathy and the mental ability to put themselves in someone else's place.

It seems to me that her great work in the humane methods for handling and slaughtering livestock was caused by her empathy for the animals and her mental ability to be aware of what they perceived and how they reacted to it.
The question of empathy was also something that struck Ann Bakeman(ph) of South Burlington, Vermont.
As the mother of an adult with the label of autism, I am tired of witnessing the portrayal of people with autism as somehow less than the complex humans they are, she writes.

The people with autism I know who almost invariably experience difficulties in sensory perception and movement that make it tough for them to negotiate the world, nevertheless are often more empathetic than some of the neuro-typical individuals around them.

They demonstrate it in many, not necessarily conventional, ways, in my daughter's case for example, by worrying about another's injury or unhappiness, apologizing when she perceives herself as the cause of a misfortune, and forgiving those who have wronged her.
Besides empathy, she and her associates have many gifts like grace and courage that too often remain un-scrutinized under the clinical microscope.
Write to us.
Just go to our Web page at NPR.org and click on the Contact Us link.
A little over two years ago, we broadcast a story by NPR's Howard Berkes about efforts by local residents to raise money to save the public library in Fossil, Oregon.
Many WEEKEND EDITION SUNDAY listeners responded to the story by opening their checkbooks to help keep the library's doors open.
Lyn Craig is vice chair of Friends of the Fossil Library and executive director of Libraries of Eastern Oregon, a non-profit group, which serves 45 public libraries in 14 counties.
She also operates the Bridge Creek Flora Inn in Fossil, where we've called her.
Thanks for your time, Lyn.
